body.name: How a Realist Hero Rebuilt the Kingdom: Volume 17

productInformation.name: Best Sellers Rank
productInformation.value: #240,119 in Kindle Store (See Top 100 in Kindle Store) #1,163 in Historical Fantasy (Kindle Store) #2,011 in Historical Fantasy (Books)

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 20, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Feels like the story is coming to a close.
reviews.reviewText: This has been one of my favourite series. I love stories that explain why they do what they do. Though the truth while satisfyingly realistic is frustratingly satisfying.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Two new wives and that’s the demon lord
reviews.reviewText: So in the new volume Souma married two new wives one from the new empire and the other from a former one and the demon lord is a anime idol AI from a alternate future.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars May be one of the best in the series
reviews.reviewText: This may very well be one of the best books in this series. It answers a lot of questions, ties up many loose ends, and sets up for an epic next arc.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 23, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Fluff and exposition - Mostly a boring
reviews.reviewText: The first 22% of the book is a whole bunch of fluff about who is marrying whom. Most of this could have been just a paragraph not a fifth of the book (according to my Kindle). For the rest, well Fuuga persuades Souma to attack the demon realm. This is the first time Fuuga's managed to manipulate Souma in this way.The two sides attack but receive some surprises. When this is resolved there's a whole lot of exposition about how and why. A lot of exposition. It's interesting for a while then gets repetitive.This book could have been a lot better but it ended up being a waste of time. The problem is I'm not sure you can skip it. It all depends upon how the next one starts. I didn't like this and if you're into the great characters and plot building of this series, you probably won't either.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 7, 2022
reviews.reviewText: It is a little sad that this story is coming to an end. But how many years has it been for Souma? I can't wait to read the next book.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2022
reviews.reviewText: A great installment to the development. Always just scratching the surface, just like milking cows in the summer. Can't wait for the next one

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Entertaining read, except for a few things...
reviews.reviewText: It is finally time for Souma's confrontation with the Demon Lord and its forces. The problem is that it is on Haan's conditions, not Souma's own, something Souma is sure leads to trouble. First though, there are marriages to perform.Much like previous volumes, I enjoy the slice-of-life parts at the start, although 25% of the book is a long bit for a marriage or two. The reveals should not come as a surprise and were ok. Much like earlier books the author also has a tendency to over explain, for example there is no need for 2 pages of text to tell person X is send to Y for research. Enjoyable characters, and for the most part a read much like previous volumes.There are two reasons though for me to give it 3 stars. There was a bit of a deus-ex-machina situation going on in the middle, both the start and resolution to a specific conflict. It made the whole thing feel like a needless chapter just added for adding a fight and making Souma feel needlessly guilty about soldiers dying under his command.The second is something I have been grumbling for some time about. I just don't like the addition of Kublai Kahn, aka Haan and for me this volume just made it worse. It makes me feel the man was added just for there to be a conflict that could only be resolved through violence. People who have no or less issues with that addition probably feel better about this volume.Still, I did enjoy the book despite the big eyeroll moment in the middle. I just hope the conflict with Haan is resolved satisfactory, even though I have no idea what I am hoping for.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on November 15, 2022
reviews.reviewText: The lore about the demons, dungeons, hero summoning, and the Demon Lord revealed at last! Not what I was expecting. Lots of laughs and few intense moments. Then setup for what happens next
I love this book looking forward to the next one and hoping for more of the anime based on the books

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on June 29, 2023
reviews.reviewText: One of my favourite series and never disappoints. The level of nuance is through the roof and the politics super involved.

This is the kind of well planned story that I love. Souma and company really know how to give you a good slice of life and administrative fantasy. Really getting Foundation vibes from this tale. And I love it.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 7, 2022
reviews.reviewText: Certainly didn't go how I thought it might, but interesting none the less, also in a way very well done info dump, the way it was handled was very good. Though I do wonder what the MC plans to do to deal with Fuuga Haan. Either way it looks like we've got to wait to find out. Regardless very well done and I look forward to reading more.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on January 17, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: Souma's character no longer makes sense
reviews.reviewText: Souma's character no longer makes sense. He now has everyone making his decisions for him in all aspects of the story except him. He has no backbone or initiative of his own. He is now a passenger in a story where he is meant to be the driver.What happened to the souma that aggressively did what needed to be done with initiative and the benefit of the wisdom he had learned?
